key_title: Key to the genera of Malvaceae

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Dicotyledons

source.author: Barker, R.M.; Walsh, N.G.
source.title: Malvaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae
source.citation: Modified from: Barker, R.M.; Walsh, N.G. (1996). Malvaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Flowers bisexual; stamens 5, often with 5 staminodes
Flowers bisexual or unisexual; stamens 10 or more, or plants spinose with 1–20 stamens
Petals conspicuous; staminodes present; capsule bristly or burr-like
Petals absent or minute and gland-like (but calyx often corolla-like); staminodes absent; capsule not bristly
Anther dehiscence sublatrorse; central (or only) staminode hairy
Anther dehiscence extrorse; central (or only) staminode glabrous
Stipules absent; calyx white, pink or brownish, not papery
Stipules present, leafy; calyx purplish, papery
[link through]
Trees; flowers unisexual; perianth petaloid, 5(6) lobed, in 1 whorl; fruit a woody follicle
Herbs or shrubs, rarely trees; flowers unisexual or bisexual, petals, sepals and often epicalyx present; fruit a capsule or separating into mericarps
[link through]
Epicalyx present, sometimes caducous
Epicalyx lacking
Epicalyx reduced to a ridge surrounding the base of the caylx; trees, covered in appressed scales
Epicalyx of 3 or more lobes; plants variously hairy, usually lacking scales
Lobes of epicalyx 5 or more
Lobes of epicalyx 3
Epicalyx 5-lobed or of 5 free segments; fruit a schizocarp with 1-seeded mericarps; stigmas 10; leaves hastate-ovate with serrate margins
Epicalyx with more than 5 lobes; fruit a capsule; stigmas 5; leaves usually lobed
[link through]
Lobes of epicalyx free to or united just above base, linear; styles clearly branched below stigmas; capsule 5-valved
Lobes of epicalyx fused in lower half into a cup-like involucre, oblanceolate; style unbranched; capsule splitting into 10 segments
[link through]
Lobes of epicalyx free from each other (but often adnate to calyx tube); low, sometimes prostrate herbs or woody shrubs
Lobes of epicalyx fused to each other; erect, often tall herbs or soft-wooded shrubs
Woody shrubs; flowers clustered; epicalyx deciduous, shrivelled at anthesis
Herbs; flowers usually solitary; epicalyx not shrivelled at anthesis
[link through]
Plants not rooting at nodes; petals not orange to red; mericarps 1-seeded
Plant rooting at nodes; petals bright orange to red; mericarps 1–2-seeded
Petals pale pink, mauve, bluish or white; indumentum of stellate and/or simple hairs
Petals yellow; indumentum of minute stellate scales overlain by stellate hairs
[link through]
[link through]
Petals yellow, white or greenish, rarely pale purple; ovary 5–20-locular
Petals blue to violet; ovary 3-locular
Petals mostly less than 1 cm long (rarely longer in male flowers); fruit a schizocarp, with 1 seeded mericarps
Petals 1–2( –5) cm long, yellow; fruit capsular, with 1–3 seeds per locule
Flowers pale purple; mericarps with spreading dorsal beak, hirsute, apex with a tuft of long simple hairs
Flowers yellow, white or greenish; mericarps lacking dorsal beak, sometimes winged or apex often raised or mucronate
[link through]
Slender trees to 10 m high; leaves glabrous, glossy green with serrate margins; mericarps distinctly winged
Herbs, shrubs or small trees to 5 m high; leaves not glossy and glabrous; mericarps not winged
[link through]
Petals distinctly yellow; stigmas capitate; flowers bisexual
Petals white or greenish; stigmas decurrent on style branches; flowers often unisexual
Petals stellate-pubescent
Petals ciliate at base, otherwise glabrous
[link through]
Flowers in axillary panicles or racemes, at least the males pedicellate
Flowers sessile (but pedicellate in L. berthae), solitary or clustered in axils; shrubs of the north-west, or a ± rosetted coastal herb
Spreading to erect shrubs to 3 m high or more; leaves mostly 5 cm long or more; damp situations, on or south of the Dividing Range
Weak shrub to c. 50 cm high; leaves to c. 4 cm long; north-west only
[link through]
